Posts.Content: Jun 7, 2008 08:45AM SandyinSoCal wrote: Melissa, I'm sorry about your experience.  I had dense breast tissue too, which increases the risk of breast cancer.  I asked for a screening MRI and was told it was clear, but two months later, a 7mm invasive cancer showed up on mammogram.  It bothers me to this day that it wasn't seen six months prior when it might have still been DCIS.  I'd already had several biopsies (benign) in the other breast, and decided on bilateral mastectomy to rid myself of my troubled breast tissue.  My doctors pushed lumpectomy also, and just a few days prior to my mastectomy surgery, my oncologist scheduled me for a biopsy of a second suspicious area, thinking I would change my mind if it was benign.  I canceled the biopsy and proceeded with the mastectomies and I have never regretted that decision.  There were no more malignancies found in pathology, but both breasts had several different types of atypical tissue growing. I made my decision because I did read stories such as yours and also had the opportunity to speak with women who'd gone ahead with bilateral mastectomy, as drastic as it seemed.   Your message is so very important and brought me to tears.  You'll be in my prayers.
Posts.Title: Read This if You Have Dense Breasts Aug242007 Aug242007

Posts.Content: Jun 8, 2009 10:05PM SandyinSoCal wrote: Karen, you may be able to have skin sparing and even nipple sparing mastectomy, and have immediate reconstruction, possibly with your own tissue.  I had immediate DIEP and traded my belly for new breasts.  Waking up with breast mounds kept me from feeling loss, and I am very happy with my result now.  If you do a flap surgery, DIEP(tummy fat)  or GAP (gluteal fat) are state of the art methods of reconstruction and are replacing TRAM (which sacrifices core abdominal muscle) and LAT (sacrifices back muscles).     You'll avoid extra scarring if you do immediate reconstruction, so definitely do your research before undergoing your surgery.
Posts.Title: How long between diagnosis and surgery or treatment? Anxiousmama katiec

Posts.Content: Nov 23, 2007 06:11PM SandyinSoCal wrote: From personal experience, I know that the California State Medical Board does not show when a doctor has been investigated; when he has been sued, or when he has settled out of court for the maximum pain and suffering amount.  No one would ever know by going there the hell I went through with my LASIK surgeon---no malpractice is hinted at on the board website under his name.  Not to mention that one of the accusations filed against him proved that he was either a liar or too blind to see what had happened during my surgery.  Who wants either for a surgeon? One way to check out a surgeon is to look up their name in the local court system to see if they've been sued for malpractice.  Even if you don't pull up anything, that doesn't mean he doesn't have any unhappy patients---as it's very difficult to get a malpractice case filed, since they are normally on contingency and attorneys are very careful when their own money is at stake.  If you do find lawsuits, at the very least you should ask the doctor what happened and let him explain.   It's awful to feel the need to check them out like this, but if you cannot get referrals from a bunch of happy patients, you need to find out as much as you can about a doctor whatever way you can.
Posts.Title: Who Should I Be Seeing? Heather_Hu SandyinSoCal

Posts.Content: Apr 16, 2009 10:42AM SandyinSoCal wrote: Dr. Chang at UCLA is wonderful.  I'd highly recommend a consultation with her.  The more opinions from experts you get, the better.  My heart goes out to you and your daughter!

Posts.Title: BedLounge back rest pillow rayhope SandyinSoCal

Posts.Content: Feb 17, 2009 11:32PM SandyinSoCal wrote: Bess, I emailed you my photos of before and after "circle" removal.  Dr. DellaCroce calls them "skin paddles".  I guess most DIEP surgeons feel better having skin on a portion of the flap on which to monitor blood flow and oxygenation, but in NOLA, they haven't used the circles for years.  I think the result is much nicer without them.   Mine were eliminated in stages because the breast skin had to be stretched quite a bit to close them up.   My breasts are not smaller as a result, but my cleavage was improved because my breasts are closer together now, and Dr. DellaCroce did a lot of fat transfer for me to fill in the hollows at the tops of my breasts.  My stage I was done in Los Angeles, and the flaps were not sutured adequately, so they slipped down on my chest within 12 weeks of surgery.
Posts.Title: DIEP Surgeries BessB BessB

Posts.Content: Oct 10, 2007 10:26PM SandyinSoCal wrote: Amy, I have had the same issue, but with an additional problem as well.  I have suture granulomas.  My sutures are not dissolving well, and my body is reacting to them.  I have lumps from hip to hip, and after one started draining out a tiny hole, my surgeon enlarged the hole to about 3/4", removed a half-dissolved suture, packed the hole, and put me on antibiotics.  That was about 5 weeks ago, and my surgery was 12 weeks ago.  I am now on my fourth type of antiobiotic, and the reaction is worsening.  I have had a lot of tummy swelling since 3-4 weeks post-op, and even had an ultrasound at one point because my doctor thought I might have a hematoma.  Now, I think it's due to the suture reaction.  You can remove the sutures that pop up through the incision.  They slide right out, painlessly.  I am wondering how bad my situation is going to become.  I feel like someone tied a belt of rocks tightly around my belly, and sometimes the incision burns from the swelling.  Hopefully, you will only have spitting sutures.  I know they can happen for a long time after surgery, in the tummy and also in the breasts.   I think that four of mine have surfaced so far.  My doctor removed three of them a couple of weeks ago when I was in for a follow-up appt. and I didn't feel anything.
Posts.Title: Spitting Stitches? amythol BRCABabe

Posts.Content: Apr 14, 2008 10:56PM SandyinSoCal wrote: I had some nausea after my second surgery, but didn't remember it until it was mentioned to me.  The next time, they gave me a couple of anti-nausea drugs in my IV, plus a scopalomine patch behind my ear right when I entered the hospital.   The combination worked great for me, but if you do have the patch and end up touching it, try to remember not to touch your eyes or eyelids without washing your hands.   Apparently, that is what I did, and one pupil became fully dilated.
Posts.Title: Waking up after Surgery maryjaneFL SandyinSoCal

Posts.Content: Oct 13, 2007 01:32AM SandyinSoCal wrote: My sutures are Vicryl---a braided material which can harbor bacteria or fail to dissolve properly.  There are many citations on the internet about Vicryl sutures not dissolving and causing problems--some severe.  I am concerned about scar tissue forming under my incision scar and causing future problems, and would love to have these lumps removed!

Posts.Content: Nov 3, 2007 03:56PM SandyinSoCal wrote: I have been back to work for a couple of months, but I cannot sit upright at my desk.  I have to lean back in my chair, and I usually only stay for 5-6 hours.    The good news is that I am going to NOLA and having my second stage on 11/9, and Dr. D is going to excise all of the sutures, scar tissue, etc. from my tummy.  I am in constant discomfort and am barely sleeping due to the binding in my abdomen.  The lumps are still increasing in size.  I think they are scar tissue.   Six more days of this......finally I will have relief.

Posts.Content: Mar 8, 2008 03:31PM SandyinSoCal wrote: My surgery last summer was 14 hours, and I awoke without the compression cuffs on my legs.  My sister, a nurse, asked my surgeon for them immediately after surgery was over, when she noticed their absence, and he said he would order them.  By early afternoon of the next day I still did not have them, so my sister went and got them herself and put them on me.  She was disgusted by the failure of the hospital and my doctor to ensure that every surgical patient has them---which is standard of care at her hospital.

Posts.Content: Dec 2, 2007 03:58PM SandyinSoCal wrote: I had a tiny invasive cancer in one breast, but decided due to my mother's death at 48 from breast cancer that I wanted bilateral mastectomy.  I didn't want to take the chance of possible multiple lumpectomies to get a clear margin, then needing a mastectomy anyway.  I chose DIEP reconstruction and knew that it could only be done once, so that made bilateral a no-brainer for me.  I wanted both breasts to match.   I got my BRCA result about 4 days prior to my surgery, and it was negative, but I didn't waiver in my decision.  There was a second area of concern in the same breast on my MRI, but I didn't even have it biopsied because I had already committed to mastectomy.   Also, I'd already had three biopsies on the other breast, and decided that I was done with the every-three-months mammograms and the stress of waiting for biopsy results.  I'm still under reconstruction but am very relieved to have made the decision that I made.  I feel that it was only a matter of time before I developed cancer in the other breast, and this way I won't have to start the surgeries all over again.   I also avoided radiation by choosing mastectomy rather than lumpectomy.  I felt that surgery was safer for my long-term health than being radiated.   Lots of little reasons added up to the decision I made.    Given my family history, my doctors agreed that my decision was a reasonable one, and I have not regretted it, not once!
Posts.Title: BRCA test impact on surgery twogirls SandyinSoCal

Posts.Content: Dec 5, 2007 11:51AM - edited Dec 5, 2007 11:55AM by SandyinSoCal During the first 10 days or so after I received my diagnosis and was told that a lumpectomy and radiation would be "all" I needed, I started off thinking "wow, I am so lucky that I just need a little lumpectomy" to having conversations with several women who'd had mastectomies in my situation, including a cousin I'd lost touch with.   As the days went by and I started looking at pictures of reconstructed breasts, I progressed from scared to death and repulsed to "I can handle that!" when I found DIEP information and photos.   Knowing that I had the option of lumpectomy still was good--helped me feel positive, but in looking toward the future and thinking about my children, the early loss of my parents, and the thought of worrying about test results every few months, my thoughts just gradually migrated to "mastectomy is safer".  Yes, the survival rate is the same for both, but the recurrence rate is higher with lumpectomies.  By the tenth day or so, I had decided that I would have bilateral mastectomy.  I just want you to know that it was a process for me, and I became more comfortable with it as time passed and I spoke to women who'd been through it.  They told me their reasons, all about the recovery, and how they feel such a sense of relief now.  I can now express the same.  I am so glad that I had mastectomies.  I have a sense of freedom from not having to worry about either breast now.  The other breast did not have cancer, but it did have prolific fibrocystic disease and I feel that eventually, it would have developed cancer.   I'm having a full hysterectomy in two weeks--I don't want to take the chance that I could develop ovarian or uterine cancer after all of this. I guess the main thing that helped me start considering the bilateral mastectomy was the option of skin-sparing mastectomy with immediate DIEP reconstruction.   Dr. DellaCroce in New Orleans does DIEP in a way that leaves very minimal scarring, and he is revising my surgery done in L.A. so I will have the benefit of that too.

Posts.Content: May 7, 2008 02:28AM SandyinSoCal wrote: Based upon my ten day bout of constipation last summer that required a trip to the ER, I would recommend starting them a couple of days before.   In addition to starting them in advance,  I was given a dose of three Colace right after my last couple of surgeries, and haven't had the same problem again.  The nurses had me drink a full cup of water with every pain pill.   I don't normally have problems, but a long surgery combined with little activity and lots of narcotics caused my intestines to shut down and it was incredibly miserable until I had a soap suds enema in the ER.

Posts.Content: Aug 22, 2009 07:12PM - edited Aug 22, 2009 07:13PM by SandyinSoCal Hi Binney---I don't think they knew!  I tried to pay very close attention.  The concept of this surgery is fascinating to me.  What you are suggesting seems really valid.  I had some truncal lymphedema after my DIEP with seroma/pseudobursa complications and went for massage therapy for quite a long time.   With the abdominal incision made for DIEP, our lymphatic system is cut into two halves.  Perhaps using a blade rather than cautery would allow for less issues with swelling (the Ken doll, etc.).  There would be more blood loss though.

Posts.Content: Aug 15, 2009 03:22AM SandyinSoCal wrote: Okay, the meeting was really interesting and we all learned a lot!  I'll try to answer the questions to the best of my ability, and when the video of the meeting is available, I'll let you know.  For now, this is the test of how well I paid attention.  There was supposed to be a handout, but that was apparently canceled.  (And do you know how difficult it is to keep 15 women from chatting during a lecture???  I did my best to pay close attention....) Who are candidates for this surgery? Dr. Massey feels that candidates will be those whose lifestyle is being significantly negatively impacted, like requiring three hours of therapy per day.   Of course there are other criteria, but basically, this is surgery and the long term SEs are not yet known.  It has been done for about 15 years so far. Must women with LE have tried standard treatment (Complete Decongestive Therapy) and have found it unworkable to qualify?  I believe so--she wants to see that a woman has tried standard therapies first, because management may not be enough of an imposition on the woman's lifestyle to risk surgery.  How about women who have had LE for many years? Yes, they can have it done.  Women with Stage III LE?     ?? I don't know enough about LE to answer that. Women newly diagnosed who have not tried other therapies? See above, try traditional first. Women with bilateral arm LE?  Yes. Women with truncal LE? Hasn't been done yet.  People with leg, abdominal and/or genital LE?  Has been done.  We saw a photo of a male patient who'd been treated successfully. How will research subjects be selected?  Can contact the Center for that information. What criteria will be used, and how long will they be followed for effectiveness and possible side effects?  There are several criteria, and I ignored Marga's advice to creat a cheat sheet.  I recall these: Pain, heaviness, measurements, number of infections per year...if I remember correctly, approximately three were completely subjective and three were objective.  What possible side effects will you be specifically looking at?  This meeting was not about the Center's planned study.  It was all about the various methods of lymph node transfer in the past, and about this new procedure---how it is done and why the previous methods didn't work, at least not for very long, and how people are benefitting from it. What method(s) are used for measuring and recording limb size for this study?   Tape measure? Water displacement? Perometry? Bio-impedence? Limphoscintigraphy? Self-reporting?  At what intervals will measurements be taken? QOL-specific testing? What aftercare specific to lymphedema will be used? Manual lymph drainage? Bandaging? Compression garment use? Specific or directed exercises? None? What guidelines for limb care will be given, and how will they be delivered and tracked? My understanding is that one unofficial measure of the success of this procedure is whether the patient still uses a compression garment or wrapping after the surgery, despite being directed to continue.  If the patient ends up comfortable enough to discontinue, that would seem to be an indication that the surgery was successful. What variables of treatment will be considered and figured into the research? For instance, chemo and rads as previous treatment? Type of surgery? Node involvement? Current drugs (including tamox and the AIs)? Use of Avastin (bevacizumab) and other drugs that inhibit the regrowth of vascular tissue? Weight gain or loss? Diabetes or other conditions that affect vascular function? Age? Stage of bc? Number of nodes removed? What provisions will be made in the study for tracking and recording possible development of LE from donor site involvement: leg, abdominal, genital LE? They believe that transferring no more than 3-4 lymph nodes will prevent problems in the donor site.  Preferably three.   Other thoughts?  Present was a female police officer who'd had LE in her shooting arm, and it was preventing her from being able to do her job.  She just recently had the surgery, successfully, no side effects, full resolution of the LE.  She is thrilled with her outcome. Thanks, MomsDaughter! Really important subject for all of us. LindaLou53, I would think that the way to determine that the lymphatic system is not impaired would be by lack of symptoms, correct?    Dr. Jay Granzow stopped by and talked with us for a while.  He is the surgeon who did VLNTx on the woman I mentioned above.  He said that if abdominal surgery has not been done previously, the 3 nodes would be taken from the abdomen--not the inguinal area.   If this is being done in conjunction with breast reconstruction such as DIEP, the flap is cut with a blade because cautery or suturing would damage the lymph vessels.  The nodes present in the flap fatty tissue would be the ones that would be transferred.   I'm guessing that the differences between doing a regular DIEP and a DIEP combined with VLNTx would be that the flap would be cut with a blade, and along with the main blood supply for the flap, additional blood vessels would be connected near the nodes.   Apparently, if the cut lymphatic vessels are set in close proximity, they will somehow establish connections on their own, so only the blood vessels require surgical reconnection.   I'd really like to learn a lot more about this---it's really fascinating.     In a week or two, the video will be online and then we'll all get to see how well I am remembering the presentation!
Posts.Title: EnCourage 8/12 Torrance, CA-Dr. Massey on Lymph Node Transfer SandyinSoCal LindaLou53

Posts.Content: Mar 8, 2008 03:22PM SandyinSoCal wrote: Chelee, my surgeon did get out an aspirating pump and try to aspirate the most swollen part of my abdomen, and all he was able to extract was fresh blood which was clotting in the needle, so he wasn't able to drain anything.  He told me that if there was a pocket filled with fresh blood, (a hematoma), that it would turn brown and liquify, and then he would be able to aspirate it within several weeks.   He sent me off for an ultrasound, but they were unable to locate it.  It wasn't diagnosed as a pseudobursa until another surgeon agreed to re-open my abdominal incision and clean it out.  I did have drainage from tiny holes in the incision for many weeks.

Posts.Title: Diary of a bilateral mastectomy twinkly pinkvictory

Posts.Content: Apr 11, 2009 02:33PM SandyinSoCal wrote: This is what I found memorable about the article: "a woman with a BRCA mutation but no cancer has a 65% to 80% risk of developing breast cancer in her lifetime. However, that risk declines to 5% after a preventive double mastectomy. A woman with early-stage breast cancer but no BRCA mutation has a 5% to 20% risk of local recurrence after a lumpectomy and radiation, which declines to 1% after a double mastectomy."
Posts.Title: Bilateral Mastectomies on the Increase SandyinSoCal jondy

Posts.Content: Aug 21, 2008 12:03AM SandyinSoCal wrote: Due to family history, I was having mammography yearly after age 33 and every six months after age 40.  I had two biopsies in the left breast that were benign, then started having problems with fluid filled cysts that had to be aspirated periodically.   I had a mammogram in 11/06 and asked about doing more surveillance and was told that I should request insurance pre-approval for an MRI.  It was approved, and I had it done in 2/07.   I was told it was negative and felt very reassured that all was well.  I had another mammogram in 5/07 and was told I had invasive cancer---just 10 weeks after the clear MRI.   The radiologist told me that there was also a second area of concern and that sealed it for me.  Bilateral mastectomy was my decision, and I have no regrets at all.   Just before my surgery, my BRCA test came back negative.  With that result,  my oncologist wanted me to have the second area biopsied, but I declined further testing.  I am so glad that I made this choice.  I did immediate DIEP reconstruction and am very happy with my results--I don't feel like I lost my breasts.  My reconstructed breasts match and I like them better than the originals.    I know you ladies are making very difficult decisions, but I can tell you that the sense of relief to be DONE with mammograms and cyst aspirations is so worth it for me.
Posts.Title: seriously considering another mastectomy paige-allyson Erica

Posts.Content: Aug 22, 2008 11:26AM SandyinSoCal wrote: rrs, yes, I had dense tissue, but not as dense as when I was younger.  I think the breast center is just too busy to catch everything.  It will always be a mystery to me why my tumor wasn't caught when it was still DCIS.  My case proves that even MRIs are not infallible.  After that, I just didn't feel safe having breast tissue.
Posts.Title: seriously considering another mastectomy paige-allyson Erica

Posts.Content: Nov 26, 2007 03:53PM SandyinSoCal wrote: My first ones were taken out at 50cc and I developed a seroma that became a pseudobursa and had to be surgically excised.  This time, we waited until they were down to below 20cc and I'm hoping for the best.  One came out at one week, the second at 15 days.  Those were the abdominal drains.  The breast drains were out within a week both times.   As a side note, I traveled for my second surgery, and my husband helped me remove my ab drains.  It did not hurt at all.
Posts.Title: How Long Was Your Drainage Tube In? SueB46 Tina337
